abstracts.cdata!:
The global environmental objectives of
            the Drylands Management Project are to reverse land
            degradation, improve biodiversity, protect rare or
            endangered flora and fauna, increase the store of carbon in
            biomass and the soils, and to maintain if not improve soil
            quality. This environmental management plan outlines
            expected negative environmental impacts and proposes the
            mitigation measures. Among them are the following: To
            increase biodiversity and carbon storage, and reduce
            invasive weeds/pests, the project will formulate a binding
            agreement with farmers and MNREP not to plough reclaimed
            pastures, provide increased market opportunities for animal
            products, reclaim watering points, and provide training in
            land management. It will also undertake soil monitoring of
            selected areas to establish the effect of better farming
            systems on soil quality and conduct farmer training to avoid
            decreased soil quality. Other impacts include increasing
            carbon sequestration and biodiversity by reclaiming ploughed
            areas with local grasses and legumes-ensuring that species
            choice is appropriate for land and climate, improving
            management of all rangelands, and installing systems to
            measure and monitor carbon accumulation. To avoid waste
            collection, storage, and disposal problems from increasing
            numbers of livestock (cattle)that may lead to waste seepage
            into groundwater and well water supply, demonstrate proper
            housing facilities for cattle that include waste management
            and the use of organic fertilizers on pastures/kitchen
            gardens, etc., take measures to prevent methane venting, and
            study the economics of waste use.
